images.caption: Figure 1:Attention sparsity for UI-TARS-1.5-7B across layers for screenshots from ScreenSpot-V2. All scenarios exhibit extremely high sparsity (mostly > 0.99) across all layers.
Figure 2:Performance comparison of KV cache methods on ScreenSpotV2. SnapKV’s uniform allocation outperforms approaches that allocate varying budgets.

Figure 3:Illustration of our temporal redundancy scoring mechanism. We first perform QR decomposition on the current screenshot at stepttto obtain a subspace spanned byQth\bm{Q}^{h}_{t}. Then, we project key vectorski′​sk_{i}^{\prime}sof visual tokens from previous frames ontoQth\bm{Q}^{h}_{t}. The magnitude of the residualρ\rho(the component orthogonal to the subspace) quantifies the visual token’s non-redundancy. In this example,k3k_{3}andk4k_{4}are less redundant thank1k_{1}andk2k_{2}since they have larger residuals orthogonal toQth\bm{Q}^{h}_{t}.
Table 2:Efficiency analysis conducted on AgentNetBench, assessed by MFLOPs per decoded token.
Figure 4:Ablation studies on AgentNetBench with various number of screenshots.
